reviewText: Regression is a polished and at times absorbing film, but the execution is unfortunately problematic.  Directed by the gifted  Alejandro Amenbar, whose sterling previous credits include Open Your Eyes, The Others, and The Sea Inside, the film is set in rural Minnesota in 1990.  As media-fueled Satanic hysteria captures the nation's imagination, a sheltered teenage girl (Emma Watson) charges her dysfunctional family with demon worship and ritualized sexual abuse.  Investigating the case is a veteran detective (a very solid Ethan Hawke) who, despite his initial cynicism, slowly begins to wonder if there is in fact a supernatural threat in play.  With its rain-swept air of autumnal desolation, this film is a triumph of hair-raising atmosphere, and it has an incredibly intriguing idea at its center:  the way a gesture, a claim, can inspire the type of paranoia which turns families and communities against one another.  Again and again, it threatens to become an engaged, focused, and hard-edged exploration of the Satanic-ritual-abuse phenomenon of the 1980s and early '90s (the false memories, the destroyed reputations), but it is distracted by an interlacing structure of overwrought dream sequences and this-cannot-be-real-OR-CAN-IT? misdirection.  The genre gamesmanship may render the film more commercial (though this hardly helped upon its unheralded U.S. release), but it also results in a deflating superficiality.  Another hindrance is a decidedly mediocre performance by Watson, convincing neither as a doe-eyed victim or as a potential small-town femme fatale (a polarity leaning uncomfortably toward victim blaming).

This is a tough one. There is so much to like about this film... and then ultimately... so much to feel "meh" about. If you watch the trailer you might be led to believe this is a supernatural thriller/horror film couched in a police procedural. Well... sort of. Without giving away the "plot twist" I can just say that where this film seems to be aiming is not where it hits home. That's fine as long as the true target is something compelling and/or intriguing. For my wife and I, this one wasn't.

Director Alejandro Amenbar, whose most well-known work to date is The Others, is absolutely a talented director. This film is gorgeous with some really compelling cinematography as well as set & costume design. Almost all the actors are fantastic, led by the always reliable Ethan Hawke. He gets some serious backing from the always stellar David Thewlis. Unfortunately, Thewlis takes a bit of a back seat here and seems a bit wasted. Dale Dickey and David Dencik also both shine here. However, Emma Watson is tasked with carrying much of the dramatic load (along with Hawke and Thewlis) and she seems a bit out of her depth. This is compounded by the fact that her character is not the most likable in film history, not to mention multi-layered, nuanced and conflicted. Watson never manages to corral all the aspects of this character into a believable and/or compelling performance.

As mentioned, while this film starts out strong and seems to be leading somewhere creepily fascinating, it ends not with a bang but with more of a whimper. It doesn't strike out, but it does lead you to think it's swinging for the fences when it actually was planning to sacrifice bunt the whole time. So the viewer will probably feel a bit let down. Some may disagree and this film might appeal more to a thoughtful person who doesn't mind a story veering off into an unexpected direction. But most will feel let down or even tricked.

If you are curious about where this film goes, you can do an online search for "Satanic Panic" or "Satanic Abuse Panic." That will give you a good idea of what this film is actually about.

***[No Spoilers]*** I picked this movie on a whim because I (1) wanted to watch a movie and (2) saw it had Emma Watson and Ethan Hawke (two actors who haven't let me down). I've seen Emma Watson in several movies---Harry Potter movies aside---which tend to be cerebral and leave me thinking for a while. I consider Ethan Hawke an underestimated actor primarily because he tends to star in B movies, but (in my opinion) carries these movies very well. This movie did not disappoint. I was pleasantly engrossed in the complex psychological investigative story line whose realism I very much appreciated. Hawke's acting carried strongly to completion and I think really fit the role. I also think Watson really fit her role and her acting was convincing to me. The overall theme and message was refreshing and nuanced. I really enjoyed watching Regression.

After watching the movie, I went onto IMDB to see what its ratings and was completely surprised at how low of a metacritic score it received. It is times like these that I think I am am either not a critical movie watcher and easily forgive mistakes. Either way, I am glad because it allowed me to enjoy this movie. Before I posted this review, I read several of the other negative reviews and I can see many of their points in hindsight, but I also noticed a lot of confusion about the story line and the overall mood of the film. I find complaints about the mood and atmosphere of the film unfounded because I thought it was fitting. Nothing pulled me out of the movie. Nothing in this movie made me suspect it was a horror film. There are horror elements---the satanic aspects---but these DO NOT define the film. It is possible that some story elements rub people the wrong way, like satanic worship and rape. If I could give advice to anyone thinking about watching this film, I'd say it is definitely a detective story worth watching. And is typical of a detective movie, you must pay attention, so no bathroom breaks without pausing the movie! And don't watch it with people that talk during movies.

A blend of genres - satanism, mystery, psychology - this film is a nuanced journey into a great mystery that occurred in 1990 in rural Minnesota.  Though perhaps a bit slow, the psychological nuance, the building fear, and the fascinating resolution make this a very worthwhile film, at least for some.

A good cop is confronted by a seemingly clear cut case of child abuse.  He sets out to investigate, uncovering first an extremely troubled family, then apparently discovering through a therapy popular at the time - regression hypnosis -  that there may be a huge satanic cult operating.  Rape, murder, even human sacrifice may be occurring in the shocked community.  The cop begins to have nightmares, unable to distinguish reality from his dreams.  He is an atheist, so denies that anything supernatural could be happening, but he can't deny what he sees.  There is a heavy atmosphere to the film, which adds to the terror.

When he finally figures out what is going on, it is really really interesting.  Because there could be many possible solutions, I do not want to play the spoiler, you have to see it to believe it.

Recommended.  Hawke is excellent as the cop, Watson is as the traumatized girl as well.

All the characters in this movie are uniformly weighed down by the heavy implications of satanic abuse that are being circulated. There's not much to distinguish one person from another. Everyone strums the same ominous chord.

Then the film is uniformly shot in somber, blue-gray tones, with constant rain as its dismal background. This does give the movie a Gothic feel. But there's just too little variation in mood and temper to propel the action.

There's also a lack of realism in the speed and hauntedness with which everyone in this film accepts the fact that Satanism is afoot. There's usually more subtlety and complexity about the way a community builds to hysteria over an issue. However, the film is rescued by its final scenes. Emma Watson does a brilliant acting job as she shows her character making a chilling turn-around - and the real source of ruthlessness becomes apparent.

This movie deals with an important issue. While the use of hypnotic regression to awaken repressed memories has pretty much been exposed as an invalid technique - one can see how there's always the danger of some other pseudo-science coming forward to capture a community's imagination. This film stands as a warning against pinning all problems on a single external source - whether that be aliens, or witches, or Satan.

This movie works okay for what it actually is: a drama exploring the real-life 1980s claims of satanic worship.  This is a well-acted, stylish film that does shed some light on why and how such claims really occurred.

The problem is that it is marketed as a horror thriller starring Emma Watson and Ethan Hawke.  In truth, it doesn't really belong in the horror genre at all (unless one stretches that genre near breaking), nor is it much of a thriller.  In addition, Watson is barely even in it; this is very much Hawke's film.  I didn't count, but I would be surprised if Watson has more than 10 or 15 minutes of screen time in total.

I watched this because it is written and directed by Alejandro Amenbar, who also wrote and directed one of my favorite horror movies, The Others.  Maybe that is why they are marketing the film as horror; that pitch did lure me in.  However, this is neither as scary nor as good as The Others.  The biggest problem is that the ending is predictable to anyone who has any recollection of the original events (and maybe even to those who don't).  I kind of remember news stories on this subject from the time, so I saw the ending coming.  As a result, the film does a good job of laying bare the emotional dynamics of the phenomenon, but it fails as a mystery.

This is recommended if you want a gritty drama about deception and guilt, and/or you are a fan of Hawke, Amenbar, or Watson.  However, if you liked The Others and are looking for another spooky mystery, this is not the movie for you.

Regression takes us back to a dark era in America, when accusations of Satanic ritual abuse spread panic and destroyed lives. For one moment, it really seemed that Satanists lurked everywhere and were abusing literally millions. The sensational accusations may seem unbelievable now, but they were believed not only by TV talk show hosts and tabloid readers, but the police themselves. After all, those who made the accusations were sincere in most cases. The film details just how something entirely false could seem very real and deadly serious. If we look further back into history, we may wonder how the witch hunts occurred. This film gives a window into such psychology. Our only blessing may be that now there is a justice system with at least some checks on such accusations, so the modern "witch" equivalents were not burned or hanged at once, or tortured into confession. Science was also able to reveal the flawed psychological techniques and theories which led to this tragedy (the "regression" of the title is the foremost among these) so it may prevent recurrence. However, we should be wary of just how easily a panic like this can take hold.

While presiding over a divorce case in the 1990's I had a case that was exactly like this story.  Fortunately I was able to see through the dynamics of the testimony and the witness's stories.  It was my experience (as a former prosecutor) that I had concluded that the problem was the social worker's interview practices which suggested and expanded upon the facts.  This was a very real problem for law enforcement back then.  In addition, the "hypnosis scenes are right on!  Typically persons under "investigative" hypnosis were usually pushed to discuss and describe the "issues" which supposedly gave rise to the investigation - usually sexual in nature.  The push is to "help" the person recall their "repressed memories" of the alleged incidents.  Unfortunately, due to a phenomenon known as confabulation, the hypnotized person will attempt to say whatever they think will please the interviewer.  This results not only in the creation of a non-existent memory, but the firm implantation of this "false memory" in the mind of the person under hypnosis.  This is one of the reasons that hypnotically "refreshed" memories are almost always not admissible in a court of law.  The movie did a great job portraying these problems!

The problem with the film (and in the reactions to it) lies not in what it is; but in what it is not. It is NOT a police procedural. It is NOT a horror film and it is most decidedly NOT a film about Satanic cults. It IS about a time in this country in our not-to-recent past when both law enforcement and the public at large went on a second series of "witch hunts" hundreds of years after Salem (and ruining the lives of countless individuals and their families) because they THOUGHT children were being abused by Satanic cults that in fact, never existed in the first place.

Regression is the story of a technique (it's in the title folks) used by psychologists and later taught to some law enforcement personnel, to aid in the recovery of "lost memories". Memories that turned out to be a product of the process itself and the reaction to it by those who were exposed.
It is a cautionary tale and an example of what happens when the imagination runs wild in the face of what appears to be scientific fact but is really, at it's core, a knee-jerk response to the mere thought that children are being abused by groups of adults to achieve evil ends or in service of evil itself.

Looked at in that light, with the understanding that the film only represents an example of the syndrome and it's process, Regression is an incredibly well thought out, well acted and well put together film. It's an inside look at what happens to good people who want to do the right thing for the right reasons who find that all their actions are based on an inaccurate premise. Because even when something looks like a duck and quacks like a duck the truth is really that it's a freaking platypus and the duck was all in your head!

WA state, to our eternal regret and embarrassment, is one of the record holders for the ultimate knee-jerk response to this process because we destroyed virtually all the lives in a perfectly respectable small town day care, it's owners and operators, employees and the children who went there along with the families who brought them in the mistaken belief that it was the well-spring of heinous crimes against children who were being used by the adults supposedly caring for them. It took YEARS, YEARS before some of these good people finally managed to clear their names and get out of jail and to my knowledge the prosecutors involved have still never admitted they were wrong.

Watch the film. Watch a basically decent man, who happens to be a detective, struggle to find the truth amidst hype, melodrama and "supposed" science while the people he is trying to protect and everyone surrounding them are all torn to pieces as the real truth finally reveals itself. See it in the light it is trying to shine on a part of our past that has proven, that in many respects, we are little different now from the villagers living in small towns all over the world hundreds of years ago

It is a cautionary tale that is both well-done and well worth viewing.

.....This is a fabulous, thoughtful AND well done movie.  The story is actually a composite of many actual stories with major features matching up with historically verifiable events of two cases in the state of Washington (mostly the Paul Ingram story but features of "Wenatchee Witchhunt" scandal 1994-1995 in it as well). It is true horror flick. My guess is that it is too scary for most because it can happen at any time to any one (including even very good families).  In addition this movie is special due to the central actors who do a fabulous job depicting the characters they play.  Ethan Hawke plays a passionate, rough, quick and dedicated detective who seeks to imprison abusers of children.  Emma Watson plays the downtrodden victim of and abusive family involved in a satanic cult.
.....The real strength of this movie is how the depicted motivations of so many people who rally to treat fantasies as fact. This facilitates repeated untold injustices. Our popular media is saturated with hyper-sexualized images in advertising along with sensationalized news reports of shocking stories that are intended to attract and rivet watchers (and the ever shrinking number of readers) to make money. The District Attorneys running for office need emotional laden cases with quick easy convictions and with little or no need for physical evidence (and data supports that in child abuse cases this works very well). Police officers are quick to restrain and jail all "threats" to women and children with a vengeance because of a natural inclination to protect victims.  Police supervisors can then ask for a bigger budget to save more "victims" so their departments enlarge.  Therapists want clients who come for help to externalize blame and "feel better" about themselves.  Accusers often need someone to blame for the tragic decisions they have made in their own lives and the repressed memory produces that person.  Clergy need to assure church members that they are active in the battle against evil and will act to protect victims from satan.  All of these motivations of disparate parties have an interest in treating every accusation of incest and satanic abuse as factually true.  Finally there is the conviction and jailing of innocent fathers, who were not perfect fathers, and often willingly accept plea bargains that allow their falsely accusing children to go free.  In this movie the father facilitates a better and more comfortable life of his daughter in a church community.  The complicated confluence of motivations are depicted very very well.
.....This is not just entertainment because it is also a literary work. The main characters change as a result of the events depicted. The viewer will change too and come away with a deeper understanding of our culture and who we are. It may not be comfortable for many to think about the issues raised in the movie. Many people have been impacted by the "recovered memory movement" and the cultural myth of "repressed memories".  Those in anyway connected to accusations arising from "repressed memories" should see this movie as soon as possible.  The police commander (in the movie) summed it up when he stated the scariest part was not only that the crack lead detective believed the accusations, but that "we all believed the accusations."
......The lone weakness of the movie  that the accuser is depicted as consciously manipulating events and using suggestive techniques to foster the hysteria.  In most events the accuser herself (overwhelming majority of accusers are female) is undergoing recovered memory therapy or regression therapy and actually believes the fantasies (often while on medication.  The movie is, I think, trying to make a clear statement that the recollections and fantasies are not factual so that the point of the movie is more forcefully made. Ive mentioned before that cults both fascinate and horrify me.  The thought that people can be brainwashed into believing even the most reprehensible things are acceptable is terrifying.  But cults that worship Satan are even more so.  For me, the religious aspect of Satanic Cults makes them an even more chilling organization.  This underlying fear is what drew me to REGRESSION, a recent release from Anchor Bay.  And I have to say:  this is one film that will stay with you after the credits roll.

Im surprised this film is not getting better reviews than it is.  It is a gripping thriller, but it also contains bold images of horror that will surprise and shock you.

REGRESSION is shot very well and looks great onscreen.  The production value appears high, and the mood and tone of the film are perfect.

The acting is excellent, with Ethan Hawke and Emma Watson heading up a great cast.  Ive enjoyed Hawkes performances for a very long time (going all the way back to 1985 when he was in EXPLORERS), and Watson once again proves her versatility as an actress.  They are joined by the talented David Thewlis, who is almost a screen legend, and a host of lesser-known (but no less talented) actors.

The plot of REGRESSION is where this film shines.  It is compelling and mysterious, and the fact it is based on true events (Im not sure how many liberties were taken) makes it even more so.  My sole complaint about the plot is that a couple of things are implied (pretty obviously), but then they are never confirmed.  This is a minor gripe, but it is enough to keep me from giving the film five stars as opposed to four.

Still, I greatly enjoyed REGRESSION, and I suggest giving it a look.  It is an evenly-paced horror/thriller hybrid that will make you question how well you know your friends and neighbors.

Well. The movie is well-done and suspenseful as a story. It is supposedly based on true events. What it is really based on is the second wave of mass hysteria that sought to sweep this issue of Satanic Ritual Abuse under the rug and label it as non-existent and a product of false memories. Yes unfortunately there were/are people who had their minds tampered with by poorly qualified therapists planting ideas in their minds, and others who simply jumped on the media bandwagon. However, that does not eliminate the fact that a variety of cults, including satanic/sadistic ritual abuse cults have existed for centuries. I have worked in mental health since the 80s to present, no, never as a therapist who did regression therapy or analysis therapy, but in activity-based allied therapy. In the course of daily activities many mental health patients rational and non-rational, psychotic and non-psychotic, have shared information about growing up in cults, being controlled and terrorized, ritual abuse, sacrifice of animals and babies, being impregnated for the purpose of providing sacrifices. You can believe this or not believe it. The highest number of these accounts was when I worked in a private psychiatric hospital in Sonoma County, California in the early 90s, where we had patients who came from not only that county but neighboring counties to the north, Mendocino and Humboldt counties,  where there were in fact many cults in existence; many were/are offshoots of the the commune movement of the sixties of which there were many in those areas. Many stories, again, believe it or don't believe it, involved highly structured and organized groups that, yes, included public officials and police departments. I have worked all over California at many different facilities but only at that particular hospital did I hear the high number of these stories and also see the high number of diagnoses of Multiple Personality Disorder, these days called Dissociative Personality Disorder, which is generally developed from extreme trauma or abuse. So, this movie wraps it all up neatly with convenient answers explaining it all and maybe that is absolutely true for this particular case it's loosely based on, but maybe it's part of the denial, I have no idea. I only know that I am a rational mental health professional who witnessed some genuinely scary multiple personality alter switching and other alarming behaviors in patients, simply in the course of doing art or social activities, not doing any sort of talk therapy, no introducing any ideas other than relaxation and stress management for coping skills which included art, communication, physical exercise, music. It's really unfortunate that this whole issue became so convoluted that any and all claims were subsequently discredited across the board.
